deliberation: Considered whether the dating formula is purely literal. The only potentially figurative element is the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to me', which personifies an abstract 'word' as a visiting agent. Treat this as conventional but still genuine personification/metonymy.

deliberation: Reviewed 'son of man', 'write for yourself the name of the day', and the siege description for idiom or metaphor. Here these function straightforwardly: 'son of man' is Ezekiel’s standard title, and 'name of the day' means date. Siege language is literal military action. No distinct figurative expression in this verse alone.

The verse explicitly introduces a מָשָׁל (allegory) and then commands actions with a cooking pot. Because these pot-instructions are not about cooking but about Jerusalem’s fate, they function as the opening of the extended pot metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וּמְשֹׁל אֶל־בֵּית־הַמֶּרִי מָשָׁל ... שְׁפֹת הַסִּיר שְׁפֹת וְגַם־יְצֹק בּוֹ מָיִם

deliberation: The detailed cooking directions (choice pieces, thigh, shoulder, choice bones) continue the allegorical pot scene. The pieces of meat represent the inhabitants, especially the elite. deliberation: Two figurative elements stand out: (1) the epithet 'city of blood' characterizing Jerusalem by its violence; (2) the city portrayed as a filthy pot whose scum remains, extending the pot metaphor to emphasize moral pollution and indiscriminate removal ('piece by piece').

deliberation: Here the city is referred to as 'she', and 'her blood' is placed on a bare rock instead of being covered with dust. The imagery conveys shameless, exposed guilt. deliberation: Again we have the epithet 'city of blood' and an announcement that YHWH will 'magnify the fire', picking up the cooking/judgment imagery. These are two related but distinct figurative expressions.

deliberation: The pot, now empty, is left on coals until its copper glows and its impurity and rust melt and are consumed. The pot stands for Jerusalem; impurity and rust represent moral defilement. This is central to the pot-as-city metaphor.

deliberation: Language about efforts and 'much scum' that will not go out, and casting its scum into the fire, continues the pot imagery. The pot’s filth stands for persistent sin; the verse personifies the pot’s resistance to cleansing.

deliberation: Here 'your defilement' and 'I purified you but you were not purified' use ritual impurity language figuratively for moral corruption. This is a conceptual metaphor—sin as impurity, discipline as purification.

deliberation: Most of the verse is direct declarative speech about judgment. The clause 'according to your ways and according to your deeds they will judge you' personifies 'ways and deeds' as agents that judge, rather than God directly. That personification is the key figurative element.

instances.english_text: According to your ways and according to your deeds they shall judge you.

prophetic rhetoric

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as verse 1. Again, 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies the word as an agent that moves and arrives.

deliberation: Key phrase 'the delight of your eyes' for Ezekiel’s wife is clearly figurative; it uses eye imagery/affection to describe a beloved person. The rest (taking her by plague, not mourning) is literal instruction about an enacted sign.

deliberation: All elements—moaning, not performing mourning rites, wearing turban and sandals, not covering the moustache, not eating the bread of mourners—refer to actual mourning customs and their suspension. They are symbolic actions at the narrative level but linguistically are described literally. No distinct metaphor/simile/personification in wording.
Straightforward narrative: Ezekiel speaks to the people, his wife dies, he obeys the command. No non-literal imagery or figurative expressions in the language itself.

The people ask Ezekiel what his actions 'are to us'—i.e., what they signify. The verse reflects awareness of symbolic action but the wording is plain interrogative prose with no overt metaphor, simile, or idiom that extends beyond normal usage.
Again the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to me' appears. This is the same personifying/metonymic pattern as in verses 1 and 15.

instances.explanation: The expression 'to let you hear with your ears' is an idiomatic way of stressing direct, experiential receipt of news through the faculty of hearing.

deliberation: Ezekiel’s mouth 'being opened' is tied to his earlier divinely imposed muteness and can be taken literally within that narrative. The main figurative element is again that he 'will be a portent/sign' (מוֹפֵת) to them.

instances.english_text: So you shall be a portent for them
target: Ezekiel’s whole prophetic existence as perceived by the people
function of his life as instruction and warning
ground: his state and actions signify what will happen to others
representative and exemplary function
didactic value beyond himself
posture: YHWH casts Ezekiel as a living symbol
metaphor of a human as a sign to highlight exemplary role
prophetic theology
instances.explanation: Describing Ezekiel as 'a portent' metaphorically frames him as a living sign whose speech and prior muteness will serve as a symbolic indicator to the people.
